Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation2: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Story: I stared at the mountain of laundry on the couch, feeling the weight of my promise to my husband that I’d finally tackle it tonight. He’d been picking up the slack all week, and I knew he was counting on me to do my part. Just as I reached for the first shirt, my phone buzzed. It was a frantic call from my best friend—her car had broken down on the highway, and she sounded scared, stranded in the dark. She needed me, now. My heart pounded as I glanced at the clock, then at the laundry, then back at my phone. I could hear my husband in the kitchen, probably expecting me to finish up soon so we could relax together. But my friend’s voice echoed in my mind, desperate and alone. I felt torn in two, guilt and worry twisting inside me. Both needed me, both counted on me, and I didn’t know how to choose.
